clinical_study.brief_title: Hypnotic Cognitive Therapy During Inpatient Rehabilitation to Prevent Chronic Pain Following Spinal Cord Injury
clinical_study.official_title: Hypnotic Cognitive Therapy During Inpatient Rehabilitation to Prevent Chronic Pain Following Spinal Cord Injury

brief_summary.textblock:
Chronic spinal cord injury (SCI) pain is complex and difficult to treat. For individuals with SCI, pain often begins early in the course of their SCI and continues longitudinally. Unfortunately, SCI-related pain is frequently not responsive to medical treatment and medical treatments that are available and commonly used, such as opioids, have negative side-effects and risk of addiction. Nonpharmacological interventions to reduce chronic pain show promise both for individuals with SCI as well as other chronic pain conditions. Research on psychological interventions for chronic pain over the past two decades has consistently found these interventions to be more effective than no treatment, standard care, pain education, or relaxation training alone. However, many of these interventions are designed and implemented in outpatient settings after chronic pain has already developed. The development of early, effective, and preventative interventions to reduce the development of chronic pain has the potential to vastly improve quality of life for individuals with SCI.
The current project is a pilot project to determine the feasibility and acceptability of offering an in-person hypnosis enhanced cognitive therapy (HYPNOCT) to patients with acute SCI engaged in inpatient rehabilitation with persistent pain. An effective, early intervention could reduce the transition of acute pain into more long-standing chronic pain, thereby improving quality of life for people living with SCI.
Aim 1: To determine the extent to which individuals with recent SCI will participate in HYPNOCT to address pain during inpatient rehabilitation.
Aim 2: To determine the extent to which patients can engage in the proposed course of treatment during inpatient rehabilitation.
Exploratory Aim: While the primary focus is to assess the feasibility and acceptability of the study intervention, the investigators also plan to explore whether HYPNOCT reduces pain intensity and interference as well as opioid use

detailed_description.textblock:
This is a two group nonrandomized pilot study to determine the feasibility and acceptability of providing hypnosis enhanced cognitive therapy for pain management during inpatient rehabilitation after SCI. Those who consent to participate will elect to be in the intervention or quasi-control condition. Following enrollment but prior to starting treatment, participants will complete a "baseline assessment." Following the end of intervention (for the intervention group) or prior to discharge (for the measures only group), participants will complete the "follow-up assessment." A brief telephone "post-discharge assessment" will be conducted at 3 months post-discharge for those who consent to this assessment. The study has 2 primary aims.
Aim 1: This trial is designed to assess if patients can be enrolled during their inpatient rehabilitation hospitalization. Feasibility will be determined by the rate of eligible patients who consent to participate. Acceptability will be determined by participant report and adverse event tracking.
Hypothesis 1a: The investigators will enroll 30 adults with SCI who report moderate to severe average daily pain of at least 3 on a 0-10 scale, who meet other eligibility criteria, and consent to participate in the intervention group of the study.
Hypothesis 1b: At least 80% of eligible patients will be enrolled, and at least 85% of enrolled participants will remain in the intervention and complete follow up assessment.
Hypothesis 1c: Less than 5% of the participants will experience an adverse event related to the intervention, and no participants will experience an intervention related serious adverse event.
Hypothesis 1d: 90% of participants will rate the intervention as satisfactory or very satisfactory.
Aim 2: This trial is designed to determine if participants can fully participate in the proposed, 4 session intervention during their inpatient rehabilitation.
Hypothesis 2: Participants will complete an average of 75% of scheduled therapy sessions.
Exploratory Aim: While the primary focus is to assess the feasibility and acceptability of the study intervention, the investigators also plan to explore whether HYPNOCT reduces pain intensity and interference as well as opioid use.
Exploratory Hypotheses: Participants who complete the intervention will report lower pain and interference immediately following the intervention compared to their baseline evaluation.

primary_outcome.measure: Rate of enrollment compared to the total number of eligible participants
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 30 days after admission to inpatient rehabilitation
primary_outcome.description: Feasibility of recruitment participates for HYPNOCT during inpatient rehabilitation admission

primary_outcome.measure: % of participants who complete at least 3 of the 4 sessions
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 30 days after admission to inpatient rehabilitation
primary_outcome.description: Feasibility of administering HYPNOCT intervention during inpatient rehabilitation admission

primary_outcome.measure: Benefit, Satisfaction, and Willingness to Continue Measure (BRW)
primary_outcome.time_frame: At follow-up assessment, an average of 28 days after admission to inpatient rehabilitation
primary_outcome.description: In order to asses if the HYPNOCT intervention was acceptable to participants, investigators will administer the BRW. The BRW is a validated yes/no measure that assesses patients' global impressions of three key elements of treatment outcome: a perceived benefit, satisfaction with treatment, and the willingness to continue treatment

primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 30 days after admission to inpatient rehabilitation
primary_outcome.description: To assess the safety of the intervention, adverse event reporting will occur at every intervention session as well as at follow-up assessment. The number of adverse events for each participate will be totaled.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At follow-up assessment, an average of 28 days after admission to inpatient rehabilitation
secondary_outcome.description: Pain intensity will be measured using a 0-10 numerical rating scale. Participants will be asked to choose a number from 0-10 that best represents their pain intensity. Higher scores indicate higher levels of self-reported pain intensity.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 6 months post-discharge from inpatient rehabilitation
secondary_outcome.description: Pain intensity will be measured using a 0-10 numerical rating scale. Participants will be asked to choose a number from 0-10 that best represents their pain intensity. Higher scores indicate higher levels of self-reported pain intensity.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At follow-up assessment, an average of 28 days after admission to inpatient rehabilitation
secondary_outcome.description: Pain interference will be measured using the PROMIS Pain interference Scale which examines pain interference in social, cognitive, emotional and physical health in the past week. Responses are scored on the T-score metric. Higher scores indicate more self-reported pain interference.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 6 months post-discharge from inpatient rehabilitation
secondary_outcome.description: Pain interference will be measured using the PROMIS Pain interference Scale which examines pain interference in social, cognitive, emotional and physical health in the past week. Responses are scored on the T-score metric. Higher scores indicate more self-reported pain interference.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 6 months post-discharge from inpatient rehabilitation
secondary_outcome.description: Brief measure of global pain interference in the past 4 weeks on a "not at all" to extremely" 4 point rating scale

secondary_outcome.time_frame: through discharge from inpatient rehabilitation, an average of 30 days after admission to inpatient rehabilitation
secondary_outcome.description: Daily morphine equivalent doses during inpatient rehabilitation hospitalization from electronic health record

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 6 months post-discharge from inpatient rehabilitation
secondary_outcome.description: Morphine equivalent doses from self-reported opioid medication use since discharge from inpatient rehabilitation.

arm_group.description: HYPNOCT is a hybrid intervention that overlaps with both hypnosis and CT to identify adaptive cognitions and make adaptive changes in cognitions more integrated into the participant's belief system (note that traditional CT uses purposeful argument and logic to make these changes; in this condition the investigators add a hypnotic automaticity to this process). The participant will relax in a comfortable position and listen to the clinician speak. However, unlike standard hypnosis for pain, the post-induction suggestions will focus on changes in cognitive content and processes (as opposed to changes in sensory experience). Participants will undergo 4 sessions during inpatient rehabilitation admission, each lasting 30-60 minutes. Sessions will include brief assessments of pain intensity, adverse events, and between session practice. Participants in this group will also complete baseline, follow-up, and post-discharge assessments.

People who consent to the measures only and usual care group will be encouraged to continue using the health care services available to them to address their pain. This includes a Rehabilitation Psychologist who can offer nonpharmacological pain management strategies. Participants in this group will baseline, follow-up, and post-discharge assessments.

intervention.description: in-person hypnosis enhanced cognitive therapy for pain management following SCI

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Diagnosis of SCI at any level or severity
- Currently admitted to inpatient rehabilitation
- Average pain intensity rating of â‰¥ 3 on a 0-10 numerical rating scale of pain intensity in the last week (at both screening and baseline).
- Reports being able to read and speak English
Exclusion Criteria:
- Severe cognitive impairment defined as one or more errors on a six-item cognitive screener
- Presence or history of mental health problems that would require referral for more intensive treatment or complicate hypnotic treatment including current suicidal ideation with intent or plan to harm oneself, current drug or alcohol dependence, lifetime history of bipolar disorder, psychosis, paranoid disorder
- Suicide attempt within the past 6 months
- Current, active suicidal ideation, plan, or intent
- Declines or is unable to provide informed consent.
